HT, I understand what you're saying, but as a physician, I am only minimally better than you at telling if someone is legitimately ill or not. If they look really sick, you can probably see it from across the room, and most often, if they are really sick, they are probably too sick to drive themselves to my office and sit in the waiting room to have me tell them that it's likely a virus and to drink lots of liquids and rest. Most of them time, they wait until they're finally feeling better and ready to return to class or work, only to discover that they can't get back in the door without a note. At that point, they have mild sniffles and their throat is back to normal, and I have to believe them when they tell me they were too sick to go to class. Likewise, if they have chronic illnesses which occasionally flare, most often I have to believe them if they tell me they are too sick to go to work. Some of my patients with arthritis, asthma, or migraines would sooner amputate their own arms than miss work for a flare; others stay home for the slightest worsening of symptoms. Most physicians do our best, but we are trained in illness. We are not trained in disability, and it can be hard to assess.
Is there evidence to support that?

Many religious fundamentalists say they only believe in strict religious interpretation of the Bible. Then they often stretch or shrink that interpretation in bizarre ways.

It seems to me that most people who become Jehovah's Witnesses are likely to do so because the group initially may seem open, welcoming, and supportive and claims to provide simple, cookie cutter answers to life's deepest questions (thus relieving the church member of the inconvenient need for doing their own independent thinking.)

It's not until later that the darker, loyalty-or-else side of the group's "honor" creed makes itself known. I think that before a new member joins Jehovah's Witnesses, the church should be required to provide a written document clearly stating that members of the church must never have a blood transfusion, and must never resign their membership. And if they do either of these things, they will be outcasts and can never, ever be spoken to again by any other family or friend who is a church member.

This sticky ethical trap reminds me of the surreal sleep medication ad on TV, with initial images and promises of peaceful, serene sleep. Then the beautiful, green, glowing, angel-of-death insect comes flying, accompanied by audio describing all of the horrifying potential side effects of taking this medication.

That "morning stretch" is the most natural stretching technique we have. It releases fascia (connective tissue) that becomes "stuck" overnight. Formal techniques that perform the very same function include Tai Chi, Yoga and static stretching.

Muscle tension relief is often elusive. This is because most fail to apply resistance during stretching. Resistance stretching is best way to remove tension from muscles. Resistance stretching requires that a muscle contract while being lengthened.

I've sufferered from plantar fasciitis off and on for years. It finally became overwhelming a few years ago. Cortisone shots only provided temporary relieve. The night boot did nothing. Stretches focusing on the calf and lower part of the foot did nothing. Orthotics helped -- but the pain came back. On recommendation of a colleague, I found a PT that discovered the problem was in my tight hamstrings and weak hips muscles. It impacted my gait (I had a pronounced wobble I didn't even realize) . Simple hamstring stretches helped a lot, but the hip strengthening (through Pilates-style exercises) really helped. She also did some medical massage. I do yoga, pilates and stretching today and have been pain free for over a year. If I skip some of that and the pain creeps back in, I stretch my hamstrings -- the impact is almost immediate.

Re Liz’ reply on April 26 to Alex's question:

The link to the Seligman article is only to the abstract. The entire Seligman article is at http://horan.asu.edu/cpy702readings/seligman/seligman.html
The article is not a research article. It is a discussion and opinion piece based on the Consumer Reports study.
The Consumer Reports study was a “volunteer response” survey. First courses in statistics or research methods teach us that these need to be interpreted with caution.
Seligman in fact says, “my guess is that it is roughly representative of the middle class and educated population who make up the bulk of psychotherapy patients” and “The CR sample, moreover, is probably weighted toward "problem solvers," people who actively try to do something about what troubles them,” and “the return rate is rather low absolutely, although the 13% return rate for this survey was normal for the annual questionnaire,” as well as other problems with the sampling for this study. Indeed, Seligman’s article mentions several other critiques of the study.

Please read the whole article; don’t just rely on the abstract or on the quote from that Liz gave from the abstract.

PS I am a "senior". I first tried therapy when I was in my forties. It didn’t help, and in fact made things worse. I kept trying again every so often until I was in my early sixties, to help deal with the problems I developed in therapy. So much of therapy just didn’t make sense to me.

Yes, there are, as you say, "30 years of outcome data and hundreds of studies on psychotherapy effectiveness," but the question is: Are the studies scientifically sound? I don't claim to have read them all, the but ones I have read have serious problems with their scientific quality. Indeed, there have been articles in very reputable journals recently suggesting that the quality of research in psychology is poor. Two examples are at http://www.nature.com/news/replication-studies-bad-copy-1.10634 (by Yong, in Nature) and http://pps.sagepub.com/content/7/6/645.full (by Ioannides, in Perspectives in Psychological Science).

"Once a Republican is in the White House, expect stimulus through government spending and tax cuts just like we had under Reagan. "

I don't know why more commentators don't understand this. The Republicans are not interested in cutting spending; they are interested in cementing their power base. To this end they have historically spent and spent. The difference is that this is Republican spending, not Democratic spending.

Jude Wanniski, economic strategist for Ronald Reagan pioneered the "Two Santa Clauses" theory for Reagan. The inestimable Thom Hartmann describes it admirably:

https://www.commondreams.org/view/2009/01/26-0

"Democrats, [Wanniski] said, had been able to be "Santa Clauses" by giving people things from the largesse of the federal government. Republicans could do that, too – spending could actually increase. Plus, Republicans could be double Santa Clauses by cutting people's taxes! For working people it would only be a small token – a few hundred dollars a year on average – but would be heavily marketed. And for the rich it would amount to hundreds of billions of dollars in tax cuts. The rich, in turn, would use that money to import or build more stuff to market, thus increasing supply and stimulating the economy. And that growth in the economy would mean that the people still paying taxes would pay more because they were earning more.

There was no way, Wanniski said, that the Democrats could ever win again."

One underappreciated reason for the housing bubble was that housing-related occupations likely absorbed many of the people who lost other jobs. Selling real estate has long been a Plan B for a lot of people who've become burned out in jobs like teaching or find themsleves limited in terms of opportunity in their chosen field. Mortgage underwriting seemed to draw younger people who were shut out of their fields and I've known a variety of people including laid off journos and filmmakers who wound up flipping houses. For people inskilled blue collar trades, occupations, sheetrock and roofing have always been the fates that they've tried to avoid. In places like Atlanta, many traditional large employers shrank their staffs and large blue collar employers like the auto companies left town. Those circumstances may explain why 20% of the employment sector their was tied to real estate and why despite only a modest bubble, the real estate sector is one of the most hard hit with people losing 20 years of appreciation in some parts of the metro area. Ultimately, property development reached a point where it could not absorb losses elsewhere in the economy. I would imagine that some of the other sunbelt bubbles had similar dynamics.

The Overland Campaign was an excellent idea. Petersburg was not the original objective, Lee's army was. The Overland Campaign consisted of attempts to flank Lee and force him to fight in the open. That Lee was able to anticipate quickly enough to have the battles fought in places like the Wilderness doesn't make it a bad idea. Further, Grant's maneuvering kept Lee from ever gaining the operational initiative.

The move on Petersburg was simply a clever adaptation that came close to immediate success and did in down Lee's army.
